thread.title: PHOTO REPORT: The 191st anniversary of the Annexation of Nicoya is a hot, lively affair
thread.title_full: PHOTO REPORT: The 191st anniversary of the Annexation of Nicoya is a hot, lively affair

author: David Boddiger
title: PHOTO REPORT: The 191st anniversary of the Annexation of Nicoya is a hot, lively affair
text:
From: To: 
The traditional tope, or horse parade, started late on Saturday and eventually passed through the city of Nicoya. Hundreds of riders come from all over the area to show off their horses, riding skills and outfits. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
See also: Water protests greet Costa Rica’s Solís in Nicoya during annual festival 
On Saturday, the people of Costa Rica’s northwestern province of Guanacaste dusted off their cowboy boots and headed out for a traditional Tico celebration at the annual Annexation of the Partido de Nicoya Festival. Held every July 25, this year’s festival commemorated the 191st anniversary of the day when the Partido de Nicoya, today known as Guanacaste, became a part of Costa Rica in 1824. This year’s event, held under a scorching sun that sent temperatures skyrocketing, was lively and hot, with plenty of protests and an equal measure of fun. 
Demonstrators from several towns in the province of Guanacaste turned out for the annual holiday in Nicoya on Saturday, July 25, 2015. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
A young Nicoyano proudly wears the Costa Rican and Guanacaste flags. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
Marimbas played throughout most of the day at Nicoya´s Central Square on Saturday, July 25, 2015. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
When Guanacaste grows, Costa Rica is ennobled. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
President Luis Guillermo Solís took the stage on Saturday to deliver a speech under the blistering Guanacaste sun. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
Not everyone complained about President Luis Guillermo Solís. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
Guanacaste is hot and rowdy and tons of fun. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
Ready for the tope, a traditional and lively horse parade celebrating Guanacaste’s cowboy and cowgirl culture. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times 
Generations of horse riders participate in Saturday’s large tope. Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
